pros:
1. Good staff welfare
21 days leave + 3 days family care leave + marriage leave + compassionate leave
Lifestyle allowance + fully paid GP visits + mobile allowance
Organises company events to encourage bonding within and across departments.
DnD to reward employees and recognise top performing sales people and teams.

2. Central office location, easily accessible

3. Some nice and friendly colleagues who can remain as great friends for a long time but this depends on your luck!

4. Good resources
Stationery cupboards will always be full! You will never run out of basic stuff to do your work here and all administrative matters (except claims) are taken care of by Office Managers.
cons:
1. Highly structured and hierarchical
A lot of levels in the bank - Senior officer, Manager, AVP, VP1, VP2, FVP, SVP, ED1, ED2, MD. If you are VP and below, you will barely be heard.
Be prepared to receive instructions from Directors with no reasons/substantiation and just carry out the orders. "Top-down" management style.

2. Low salary

3. Very traditional management culture
To get ahead, you need to be good in office politics and pleasing your seniors.

4. Old systems
The systems used in the organisation are very outdated. However, UOB is attempting to rebrand itself as a digital leader through its digital initiatives like Finlab, digital bank etc, playing catch up in this industry.

Overall, if you are looking to learn a lot and grow exponentially in your career, I'd recommend that you look elsewhere. Eventually, it is still a traditional family business. The unhealthy culture permeates through the organisation.

An entire cohort of senior mgmt needs to retire and allow the digital transformation to take place across depts and the bank needs to want to do that. 

Ineffectively leadership with old china-man style mentality. Male dominant thought the female senior leaders are really good at what they do.

The bank lacks cultural inclusivity, lacks world-class regional banking HR standards are very poor. HR allows corporate bullying of some senior guys as they've no way to manage these "related" individuals. 

Overall, still, very much a family-owned bank filled with nepotism and favorite individuals who may not necessarily be competent in their work or performance. People, Process & Technology makes Digital Transformation. At the heart of it, Culture.

cons: Silo mentality exists and rivalry between sectors is rife. Systems are state of the art only in the 80's so everything is running at snail speed. Too many divisions exist to "dictate" policies when what is needed are resources to implement and execute them.  Pay is a joke especially at junior to middle management levels compared to the competitors.

System sucks. Honestly, it has been pretty long since I last saw the standard start up page for Windows 7. Good ol’ days. There were computers that are still using Excel 2010/13. Their systems sucks. It will take hours to load environment simulation and worst of all, it might crash after waiting. After awhile, you will just get used to being unproductive ‘due to system issues’. Management failed to recognise the importance of upgrading its IT because they have lost touch of how the work process is like. 
Generally, it is a reactive company. In this covid19 situation, Wfh arrangement were prepared and activated at the very last min.

pros: really nothing to write here

review_title: Bank finding its way to former days of glory
pros:
It might be a good place for bankers from foreign banks to seek refuge in.  

The management believes the holy grail is in the form of new hires (or former bankers from foreign banks).
cons:
1. The Finance department is a mess.  There is a reorganization/ transformation /cost cutting (whatever you call it) every 1-2 years.  
2. There are many long time employees that call the shots.  Even their bosses or the CFO cannot or dare not do anything with them.  It's usually the newer employees (not longer than 7 years) that would take the blame or made the scapegoat.
3. Because of constant reorganization, there is lack of clarity in job roles & responsibilites, not to mention that certain department heads are unhappy and thus generally a poor and negative working environment.
4. many MDs!  This is not an investment bank & yet there are multiple MDs.... There is an MD who reports to his boss (an MD), who may report into another MD.  Because there are so many MDs, some EDs who are not made MDs are unhappy.
5. Generally spends too much time & effort on non important issues, like 'should we or should we not do away with per firm?'  Nobody decides, so consensus is sought....

review_title: Awful. Other than the fact I get to take initiatives and be in control of my own projects/tasks
pros: If you have the drive to motivate yourself, there are lots of projects for you to handle.
cons: Culture/People. Sticking with their old values and unwilling to accept the fact that the firm/process/system need to change. Older workers that come to work everyday just to pass time and focus in their routine BAU task. Unwilling to take on new initiatives/projects. Staffs spent more time badmouthing others and form inner cliques/create unnecessary politics than working. Poor leadership and communication skills. Managers/department head were unable to provide clear directions in tasks/projects and when things do not go in the way they want, they will exercise their only strength, which is to play the blaming game. Would suggest UOB staffs to take on courses to improve their articulation and communication skills.

pros: HR benefits quite competitive and good
cons: i was working in uob as a rm selling financial products and it was the worst part of my working life. morale among my colleagues were super low and almost everyone i know has left for another bank. our customer port was pathetic and we are being grilled daily for not being able to sell to these people. the mgt attempts to solve this morale issue by tracking our activites that attempts to tell us our problems and our managers are tasked to apply a "remedy" to us. when the results on this tracking report doesnt look good, we are being scolded by the managers who obviously got it from the top mgt as well. the worst part is that mgt is so blinded to their own pride to think that everything they implemented is working smoothly. thank god i have moved to another bank and no thanks to uob for the very unpleasant experience.

review_title: Good starting bank, decent retirement home - not for the ambitious
pros:
Great people - lots of hardworking and driven individuals, regardless of rank or seniority.
Good hours - 6.30 EOD is common, even in traditionally 'rougher' departments e.g. IB, Markets or Corp. Banking.
Strong values.
cons:
Highly bureaucratic - multiple layers before you get anywhere near pitching ideas to top management. 
Relatively low pay (but then again, UOB is not a foreign bank, so do manage your expectations).

pros:
- Company is transforming fast and catching up on the tech front, there is alot of potential
- Good business acumen by top management
- New HR organisational changes will hopefully refresh culture and bring positive changes
- Generous with budget to carry out projects
- Benefits are standard (compared to other big banks)
cons:
- Lack of synergy in brand and communications efforts because it is the only organisation that has this function split into two different divisions. power struggle at the top is evident.
- certain depts are infamous for their poor leaders, but despite annual bad reviews they are still there, not sure if HR is doing their job to assess leadership qualities. high turnover in certain depts are tell-tale signs.
- CEO tends to be on the conservative side

review_title: Expensive seniors not pulling their weight
pros: Friendly working environment. Long-time working level employees are generally nice and willing to help.
cons: The Bank has been spending a lot more in staff expenses in recent years to bring in many senior hires from foreign banks and consulting firms. This is evident from the group’s financials. However, many of these expensive hires are not pulling the weight and it has an impact on staff morale. Such a senior person can easily command a few times salary of a working level AVP/VP and yet their jobs are not measurable. There is also abuse of authority in some MDs bringing in their friends from ex-banks to fill up newly created redundant roles or when that failed, these people are placed in roles that they do not have the skills set for.

pros: I recommend seeing my Cons.
cons:
Unethical, non-compliant to MOM working hour standards, no overtime pay. All they care about are the amount of INSURANCE closures you can make. Has absolutely nothing to do with banking. A bank teller will know more banking functions than you do. Your life is based around roadshows and what they call "ATM Tagging" where you stand by the ATMs to harass customers withdrawing their cash to mislead them into signing a suboptimal endowment insurance policy with you. You work 6 days a week from 0930-2100 or 1100-2100 HRS.

The workplace has a toxic work culture and classes bosses who could barely speak proper English. They recently implemented a $5000 bond on all Personal Banking Associates who decide to leave the job within 9 months instead of resolving why they have such high turnover rates. I strongly recommend against working at UOB as a Personal Banker unless you want to experience what it is like to be bossed around like a slave with bosses who can't even communicate properly. 

It really is a place that exemplifies the phrase "A person's title can never buy class nor character".

pros: My manager is willing to take me onboard even though I do not have the technical know-how then. I repay his trust by learning the ropes quickly and be productive.
cons:
Most managers in UOB aren't having that mindset. Instead they find joy in criticising their subordinates though I find it really unnecessary. 

Navigating the jungle of processes is an extreme nightmare - most of which are definitely non-value-adding tasks, such as seeking managers/team leaders for paper signature. It isn't difficult to guess what happen when they go on leave or are not the best person to get along with. It isn't exaggerating that 50% of your time is spending doing these unnecessary work. There are instances where I have to work throughout the night.

Other banks are talking about Agile/Scrum development methodologies but sadly the company have not grasp the concept of SDLC.

review_title: Worst Sales Platform of all Banks
pros: UOB as a brand on the outside seems good, however the world does not know what is happening inside the company.
cons:
Worst ever , managers only know how to talk talk talk & make you call and set appointments with customers...hopefully to bring sales. Otherwise, they will blame it on your competency issue. Lousy treatment and no welfare of staff. No work life balance at all. Not worth your time or effort in this company at all and mostly foreigners can work here only. So many Bankers have left the bank and from what I see only the incapable management can stay as they are micro managing the life out of Bankers. 

My commission and earnings is also delayed ... so do not bother as it is a trap. Their role is so bad that they need to make advertisements in order to attract people into the personal banking role. Ha ha ha

Disclaimer: all this are just my opinions based on personal experience and factual occurrence, and up to you whether you want to take it as face value to believe.

pros: u get to work with lots of locals compared to other nationality
cons: employees who stayed back just to wait for HOD to leave the office, and less than 5 minutes, all pack their bags and leave. Employees who are related to the board of directors and they are there in their cushy job, and everyone will try hard to get into this employee good book

pros:
- Reasonable salary of 2.7k base + 500 allowance.
- Good training program
- Commission if able to hit sales target
cons:
- Sales and numbers. Cannot hit sales you're out. Always hard sell and push products. 
- Only sell endowment for first six months
- No work life balance
- Six months into the job makes you feel like you've aged five years
- Management was unreasonable
- will be pressured if no sales,  will be scolded due to paperwork gliches when there's sales
- A lot of team bonding using your own money
- Management expects you to take cab at your own expense and travel whole Singapore to meet client or do errants
- Long working hours, work on weekends
- Have to work on roadshow and begs people to listen to you. More like retail salesperson than banker

review_title: Family environment but slow to progress
pros:
Friendly colleagues, family-like environment. 
Plenty to learn if you are willing, though learning curve may be a bit steep at times.
Staff benefits are quite good though, especially in terms of medical.
cons:
Slow to adopt new technologies. 
No work-life balance. 
Management tend to overload the capable ones; ad-hoc projects, team management, all pile on top of daily work. Inevitably will result in burn-out or the person just up and quit.  
No real push from mgmt to equip staff with tech skills; probably the senior mgmt are not that tech-savvy themselves?
Style of management tend to be very top-down, employees are not aware of the big picture.

review_title: Branch officers suffer crazy workload, nonstop sales targets  with okay salary and benefits
pros:
If you work hard, and manage to have successful referrals for loans and such, there is extra money or vouchers to be earned every month.

My direct bosses are good people who do care about us.
cons:
Work hours is complete nonsense. Branch staff are totally overloaded. We are in charge of branch operations, ensuring that the ever growing list of compliance things are followed, branch sales, branch service standards. And on top of that, track sales, track compliments, handle customer complaints. Doing a lot of stupid and unnecessary things.  The list goes on and on. You handle retail customers. You handle corporate customers. You are expected to know everything if not customers will question why are you representing the bank when you do not have the knowledge. Loans, cards, deposits, universal life insurance, cx, business loans, compliments, account opening. What else you want us to be in charge of? 

Expected a lot out of the position. But pay does not at all justify the workload.

Senior management do not understand the difficulties at branch and that’s real sad.

pros: slow paced, nice office building in raffles place, large network of branches and wide range of products.
cons: long hours. old fashioned bosses seem to measure productivity based on who stays back later in the office. too many layers of management is stumbling block to fast execution. different layers want different things. confusing and lack of clear direction for staff on the ground. top management expect products to sell without competitive pricing. in todays digital world with transparent price comparison online, expectation is laughable and unrealistic. staff who work quietly go unnoticed. bosses favour and recognise those who talk alot including empty vessels, breeds unhealthy work culture and demoralise hardworkers. gotten too political over the years.

review_title: Great place to learn, but development and pay can be lacking
pros:
- Friendly colleagues, everyone is usually willing to help
- Job security
- Bosses generally approachable and keep things professional
- Business is stable, management adopts a very long-term outlook, does not usually suffer from short-termism
cons:
- Pay is not always competitive, or equitable. Cases of newcomers sometimes earning close to what experienced employees are earning
- Management is not always open to new ideas/prefer to maintain status quo, depending on your department, prefer to take baby steps instead of embracing big changes

pros: A good place for youngsters to venture to other business within the bank or outside to foreign bank.

Middle management (AVP-VP) suffers most as the top over-delegates/over-expects but the bottom are freshies who need to be spoon fed.
Colleagues may seem nice on surface but no one is really sincere and upfront. Poor brand name. Being HO, a lot of admin work. Never work so hard in my life yet so poorly paid and recognised. 
Bonuses are elusive, always subject to own team, sector and bank performance!

review_title: Horrible place that will waste your time if you are at your mid to late 30s.

cons: Highly exploitative. Bonus is never based on real performance but on economic outlook. The bank will cut bonus even if it did extremely well last year just because forecast outlook is gloomy. Sure no win because management is the shareholder themselves.

There are many employeeds at UOB that have started and finished their careers with the bank. This speaks about the loyalty and affinity towards the bank. While most banks are taking advantage of the current market conditions to make their organizations leaner (Layoff Employees), UOB has not taken any such steps. This shows that the UOB management has a heart and I respect them tremendously.
cons: Salary needs to increase across the board. Corporate culture needs to change.

Ridiculous analogy. Staff have to do extra curriculum to get promoted instead of real work knowledge and efforts.

review_title: Tough at first breaking into the community but getting better as the years pass by and the relationships are developed
job_title: First Vice President in Pasir Panjang,
pros: Recognition is not bad if you are doing well. People are also helpful after you get to know them better. Growing bank so get to do many pioneering stuff.
cons: It's not a very professional place working place. People re cliquish. Some bosses are rude and discouraging. No employee satisfaction survey.

review_title: People need to feel that their work matters, by accurately evaluating their performance.
pros: Being in a small branch means you can be part of a close knit community.
cons:
1. Actual work does not roll up or reflect in KPI/OKR. In branch operations, about 60-70% of the time is devoted to handling day to day transactions and customer requests which means a lot of paperwork(I will get to that later). The scores that’s reviewed at the end of each month/quarter/year only covers 20% of the work that was done, but has an overall weightage of 80% of the total performance of an employee. That 20% is: up-selling/cross-selling of loans/cards/...and wait for it... Personal Internet Banking. 

2. Company direction not aligned with overall company focus. Overall, UOB wants to be a tech savvy financial institution and in Group Channels, it manifested mostly as “selling Personal Internet Banking”. This placed most of the responsibility on the branch employees to find ways to up their numbers. Some by resorting to cancel active account and sign these users up a second time. A better option would be to look at the time consuming and paper dependent workflows that all customers are required whenever they step into a branch. I presume things are much better now but back in 2015, everything had to be filled in pen and paper, and one spelling mistake or bad handwriting would be your worst nightmare.

3. People managers not equipped with the right skills. This may not be applicable to all branches, but in the particular branch I worked for, the manager was promoted simply because she was superb at sales. She failed miserably at people management and thus made everyday miserable for everyone and herself. Looking back, I wouldn’t say she was intentionally breathing down everyone’s neck or manipulating people to control them, but I think these are the methods that she was aware of/exposed to. Another reason could be that people’s welfare or overall satisfaction with their managers were not measured, and thus does not contribute to her overall performance review. Without this feedback channel in place, managers are not getting the right help to help their employees.

4. Too much importance placed on frivolous activities. This is purely my personal opinion and may be very skewed given the environment I was in. The channels group often had completions for cheerleading, dancing and other performance which are affectionately named “CCAs”. I understand the well meaning - to build relationships between branches and to promote life outside work- but it clearly has backfired when people started realising this is the only way to climb the ladder quickly (and not by doing a good job at work).  Also it’s almost impossible to feel that you have a balanced grasp of your life and work when there is a ton of paperwork piling at the branch, while your manager is calling you to go down for dance/cheerleading practice. Good intentions, bad execution.

5. Lastly, I just HAVE to add, the fake surveys. How UOB measures customer satisfaction is pretty intriguing. Every month employees will collect feedback forms from the walk-in customers. Given that this is a hard target and you have to have at least 2 per month (or you will be deemed as incompetent and disqualified for the Quality Awards), not all of the feedback forms were actually filled by actual customers. Most were signed my gullible and unknowing customers, and then later filled in by the employees themselves. Some were written by actual customers of course, maybe 10% of all submission. Again, another good intention scheme, execution gone wrong.

pros: Family orientated, colleagues and bosses can be nice depending on your department, job stability is there. Average salary and benefits

review_title: Stay away if you're looking for a workplace with good work-life balance
pros:
*Major banking institution in ASEAN region (Top 10) so it would be good for your resume

*Stable. Once hired and provided your are capable, you won't need to be afraid of getting laid off anytime soon

*Proper documentation and workflow. Everything here is so coordinated. They even user JIRA to log any issues or request and the business team also abide this.
cons:
*Dog eat dog world. Let me give you an example. The PMs don't care if you're doing improper testing. All they care is you sign the signoff form so one misstep and it's going to come back to haunt you later hence the need of this "dog eat dog" mindset else you get trampled

*No work-life balance. Yes, 100% agree. You are expected to work long hour sometimes till 10PM. Even weekends if need be including Sunday. At least in my previous workplace, Sunday is a sacred rest day.

*One bank concept. UOB is unique in a sense even with their overseas branches, they still consider them as one UOB. Everything is centralized. Development has to be coordinated and done with UOB Singapore. While in theory it's good, the reality is not. It's bureaucratic nightmare. Most of the time, you have to liaise between in-country team and Singapore team during testing. Let's not forget due to this centralization putting a lot of strain to Singapore which resulted me, an oversea team, being neglected until the project due date most of the time

review_title: Go only if you have no other choice and need some money
pros: Only thing I managed to take away was masks. lol
cons:
You are just another insurance agent masking as a "banker" and everyone knows it
Expect no support internally, you are only there to generate revenue. You are just a number for them to hit their insurance target with prudential for management to collect their bonus
You already have a bad rep all over when people hear you are from UOB. Too many bad experiences by customers. So expect just to be used by low class client to waive their credit card fees which itself is a pain. 
And can you believe a bank that makes billions actually still expect us to fax documents?! LOL
Client once told me "UOB is very transactional". Which I have to agree that is the culture inside also. Stealing of clients is rampant and superiors don't care as long as the client is generating revenue for the bank, they don't care who transact so everyone will poach your client by undercutting you. Which in fact the bank loses out. Very short termism but that is the way.

pros:
Work life balance
Generally cooperative co workers
Despite the comments below, the bank has some very good managers in certain functions.  They keep a relatively low profile and work for the good of the bank.  I wonder if senior management knows of them (instead of allowing for double / rapid promotion by some of the other driftwood functions).
cons:
Many are promoted because their boss likes them, no round table review.  Thus, common to come across SVP or Directors  who are rather incompetent.
Weak in risk management, compliance and treasury functions.
Not creative.
Senior management at certain functions clearly not motivated to work.

review_title: Boring operation job, traditional company, no creative, no energetic, no improvement.

pros: benefits: 24 leave day, got dental& spectacular RM600, fee medical on panel clinic, free medical check up RM300 once in 2 years.
cons: -boring, low performance bonus, old traditional, conservative company, unwilling to change(only in operation department), company facilities are old and limited, insufficient toilet (50 staff only 2 toilets), simply transfer staff to another without staff permission(1st day join UOB but simply transfer to another department without notice), no OT allowance

review_title: High workload, relocates in different department to surge volume(not fix in one department), peaceful and harmony
pros: Harmony, less office politics culture.Back on time without guilty(no OT claim), suitable to women who married and the person no willing to change, less stress.
cons: Back end operation: limited learning and improvement, high workload, no OT for executives (no Uunion support, only clerk applicable), low increment  less than 10%, stay with long service staff(old senior staff) so is not suitable for young energetic generation. Limites benefits for staff not work in HQ. Low bonus for back end staff.

review_title: Lack of diversity, weak IT infrastructure, indecisive management
pros:
Good work life balance, typical work hours 9am-7pm, rarely need to work on weekend.
Performance assessment is quite fair
Management is receptive to employee suggestion
cons:
Salary is lower compared to other local bank
Lack of on the job training, employee will not learn much compared to foreign bank
IT infrastructure is very weak
Employee diversity is low, socializing will be a challenge if you cannot speak Mandarin
Management incapable of decision making, everything is delegated to SVP/CEO
Lack of communication between department, everything work in silo
Too many layer of bureacracy

review_title: OK work-life balance but compensation not competitive
pros: UOB is a local bank. The pace is slower than foreign banks which means alot of work-life balance, generally understanding towards personal issues to take time off.  Medical benefits are satisfactory. People are generally nice. Annual leave benefits adequate.
cons: Compensation not competitive.  Culture does not promote excellence, promotion not based on meritocracy.  Very bureaucratic, hard to get things done across departments.
